questions.prompt: The PN-junction diode equation is i = Is(e^(v/VT) - 1). What is VT at room temperature (T = 300K)?
For a silicon diode with Is = 10^-12 A at room temperature, the current at v = 0.6V is approximately:
In deep reverse bias (v << 0), the current through a PN-junction diode approaches:
questions.explanation: For v << 0, e^(v/VT) approaches 0, so i = Is(0 - 1) = -Is. The current is -Is (reverse saturation current).

questions.prompt: The PN-junction diode is classified as a:
questions.explanation: The diode equation gives i as a single-valued function of v (voltage-controlled), the relationship is exponential (nonlinear), and there are no time derivatives (memoryless resistor).

questions.prompt: If you increase the forward voltage on a diode by 60 mV (at room temperature), the current approximately:
options: C) Increases by a factor of 10
questions.correctAnswer: C) Increases by a factor of 10
questions.explanation: In forward bias, i is proportional to e^(v/VT). A 60 mV increase means delta(v/VT) = 0.060/0.026 = 2.31 = ln(10). So the current multiplies by e^2.31 = 10.

questions.prompt: Two identical diodes carry currents i1 = 1 mA and i2 = 10 mA at the same temperature. The voltage difference v2 - v1 is approximately:
When temperature increases from 300K to 350K, the thermal voltage VT:
questions.explanation: VT = kT/q is proportional to T. At 350K: VT = (350/300) * 26 = 30.3 mV, approximately 30 mV.

questions.prompt: The reverse saturation current Is of a silicon diode is typically:
questions.explanation: For silicon diodes, Is is very small, typically in the range of 10^-12 to 10^-15 A (picoamps to femtoamps).

questions.prompt: The ideal diode model is the limiting case of the PN-junction model as:
questions.explanation: As VT approaches 0, the exponential e^(v/VT) transitions from smooth to infinitely steep at v = 0, approaching the ideal diode's sharp two-segment characteristic.

questions.prompt: Is the PN-junction diode passive or active?
options: A) Active, because it is nonlinear
B) Passive, because its v-i curve lies in quadrants I and III
C) Active in forward bias, passive in reverse bias
D) Neither; passivity only applies to linear resistors
questions.correctAnswer: B) Passive, because its v-i curve lies in quadrants I and III
questions.explanation: For v > 0: i > 0 (quadrant I, p = vi > 0). For v < 0: i = -Is < 0 (quadrant III, p = vi > 0). The curve stays in quadrants I and III, so the diode is passive.
